) Audience: The primary users of the IRM are all IRS employees in Business Operating Divisions (BODs) who are in contact with taxpayers by telephone, correspondence, or in person. (
) Policy Owner: The Director of Accounts Management is the policy owner of this IRM. (

) Program Goals: Program goals for this type of work are: • Achieve a high customer accuracy rate for phone calls and paper cerning general claims • Efficiency in resolving general claims • Continuous assessment for program vulnerabilities and opportunities improvement • Effective communication with customers The Accounts Management Program Letter provides additional information garding these and additional program goals. ) The Accounts Management Director oversees the instructions to the employees contained in the IRM content. (
) Accounts Management Policy and Procedures IMF (PPI) Tax Analyst(s) oversees the content in this IRM and acts as a point of contact for all Management sites. (

) Employees resolve General Claims Procedures requests following in this IRM. (

An informal claim is a claim that is submitted in a manner other than on the standard forms re- questing changes to obtain the correct and accurate reﬂection of a tax liability or tax credit. Informal claims can also include oral statements made by the taxpayer if the IRS has documented those statements in writing.
(10-03-2022) What Are Claims Credit, Refund, and Abatement?
Example: A claim for refund can be an amended return or written request that decreases tax, decreases a penalty, and/or increases a credit where all
or a portion of the prior tax and disputed penalty assessments have been paid, and a refund is requested.

Example: An abatement request can be an amended return or written request that decreases tax, decreases a penalty, and/or increases a credit claimed on the return and results in the reduction of the module balance.

) The Where’s My Amended Return” (WMAR) application provides automated online and toll-free telephone services. Advise the taxpayer that the best way to get the most current information about their amended return for the current ″ tax year and up to three prior tax years is by using the Where’s My Amended ″ Return? (WMAR) application. Access is available online from the home page on IRS.gov or by telephone using the toll-free number
(must use a touch-tone phone). Access is fast, accurate and available
hours a day,

days a week from any computer with internet access, and the information provided is speciﬁc to each taxpayer who uses the tool. By entering their SSN/ ITIN, Date of Birth and Zip Code into the WMAR application, the taxpayer will be able to ﬁnd out the status of their Form

-X Amended Return(s). WMAR is designed to track the status of amended returns as they are processed. This will provide the taxpayer with a consistent message and reduce the number of amended return status calls. IDRS transaction codes (TC) (e.g.,

This section discusses general claims procedures. Always begin by following the procedures for disclosure in IRM 21.1.3, Operational Guidelines
Note: To determine if a claim is received timely, see IRM 25.6.1.6.15, When a Document Is Treated As Filed Under the IRC.
(3) When a claim is submitted, determine if it is complete. All the following require- ments must be met before a claim or amended return is considered complete:

a. Filed on a permitted form or in an informal written inquiry and includes everything necessary to input a correct adjustment. b. Contains sufficient required information to permit the mathematical veriﬁ

cation of the amount shown on the claim. c. Contains the name, address, and Taxpayer Identiﬁcation Number (TIN) of the taxpayer and is signed by the taxpayer (if a joint return, both taxpayers) or authorized representative under penalties of perjury (also known as the jurat).

Reminder: Do not attempt to secure the return or request additional information from the taxpayer if enough speciﬁc information is available with the claim or with the various Integrated Data Retrieval System (IDRS) command codes.
Reminder: Refer to IRM 21.5.1.5.6, Incomplete CIS Claims, for additional informa- tion regarding CIS claims that are incomplete.
Once the claim is determined to be complete and processible, determine if:
a. Statute date is still open. Exception: Taxpayers may still be entitled to a refund on some claims for abatement/refund ﬁled after the normal Refund Statute Expi- ration Date (RSED). Refer to IRM
, Submission of Additional Information Necessary to Make a Determination on the Claim After the RSED, for additional information.

, the Supreme Court issued a decision in California et al. v. Texas et al., a constitutional challenge ﬁled by several states and individuals, to the validity of the Affordable Care Act. The Court dismissed the case on the grounds that the plaintiffs did not have the standing to challenge the law. As a et al. result of the Supreme Court’s ruling, the Service will not allow any protective claims for refunds held in suspense. Instead of issuing disallowance notices to all taxpayers who ﬁled these protective claims, the IRS issued a generalized announcement, IRS Statement — Supreme Court Ruling CALIFORNIA ET AL. v. , a taxpayer is granted an extension of time to ﬁle, if the taxpayer meets all the following requirements: • Failed to make an election solely because the taxpayer failed to timely meet the requirements in Rev. Proc

Exhibit 21.5.3-4 (10-01-2011) First-Time Homebuyer Credit – Additional CAT-A Criteria

The Worker, Homeownership and Business Assistance Act (WHBAA) provided additional authorities regarding the First-Time Homebuyer Credit (FTHBC). As a result, the FTHBC review procedures and Category A (CAT-A) criteria have been modiﬁed to include instances when a FTHBC claim will be “no considered”, disallowed, or referred to CAT-A. Details regarding the “no consider” and disallowance criteria are in IRM 21.6.4.4.17, First Time Homebuyer Credit.
Note: Math error responses on an original return are not claims. See IRM 21.5.3.2, What are Claims for Refund and Abatement? See IRM 21.5.4.4.2, Math Error Response Categories.

Exhibit 21.5.3-5 (01-19-2010) First-Time Homebuyer Credit Automated Tool

An Integrated Automation Technology (IAT) tool is available as part of the xMend tool to perform research related to the First-Time Homebuyer Credit (FTHBC). The tool will research existing taxpayer information provide a response for the processing of the claim, including referrals to CAT-A or disallowance of the claim.
Note: The IAT tool may be unavailable at certain times due to programming updates. Manual review of the different criteria is required if the tool is unavailable.

Prior to running a FTHBC claim through the tool, ensure the claim is complete. Claim requirements speciﬁc to the FTHBC are outlined in IRM 21.6.4.4.17, First Time Homebuyer Credit. In certain instances, the claim will be “no considered”. The tool cannot check the “no consideration” conditions.

If one of the no consider conditions exist, the claim must still be checked for possible disallowance conditions. a disallowance condition exists, the claim will be disallowed. Exhibit 21.5.3-6 (05-22-2017) Fraud Referral Claims

A fraud referral database (FReD) has been created that enables potential tax fraud or non-compliance leads to be disseminated and subsequently acted upon. The database does not replace any existing referral methods.

Employees who discover a questionable case will refer the case to their lead or manager. The employee will maintain an open control base and suspend the case while waiting for a response. Update the IDRS activity to “REF
FRED” after suspending the case to the manager or lead.

The lead or manager will review the case to ensure fraud referral criteria are met. • If criteria are not met, the case will be returned to the employee with a message advising why fraud referral criteria were not met. • If criteria are met, the lead or manager will refer the case information to their local fraud referral coordinator via E-mail indicating why the case was referred and the CIS case number. AM Fraud Referral Coordinators can be found on the Accounts Management Fraud Referral Coordinators website. Caution: The case will remain in “suspense”inventory for
days and if no action will be returned to the employee in their “active” inventory. Do not take action on the case until appropriate guidance has been provided.

The fraud referral coordinator will review the case to ensure fraud referral criteria are met. • If not met, the fraud referral coordinator will send an E-mail to the lead / manager advising why the criteria were not met. • If met, the fraud referral coordinator will access FR

to see if the issue has already been identiﬁed. • If the issue has not been identiﬁed, access CIS, convert the CIS case image to a PDF ﬁle, submit a new report (from the link above), input the required ﬁelds and attach the case information.

) will get input from CI, Return In- tegrity & Veriﬁcation Operations (RIVO) and / or other impacted functional areas to develop guidance. The referral team will respond to the fraud referral coordinator within
business days via E-mail. Note: The Fraud Referral Coordinator should follow up with the FR
Team if a response is not received within
business days.

business days of the original submission providing the appropriate actions needed.
The lead / manager will attach the E-mail guidance to the CIS case by converting the E-mail to a PDF ﬁle.
